author: By Grace Lin
title: How Did Ancient Cultures Experience Reading?
description: The first book in David Bowles’s new graphic novel series, “Rise of the Halfling King,” shows kids how a hieroglyphic script might have captivated the Mayans.
content: RISE OF THE HALFLING KINGTales of the Feathered Serpent, Vol. 1Written by David BowlesIllustrated by Charlene Bowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can Your Apartment Building Ban Overnight Guests?
description: A patchwork of laws governs how buildings can restrict visitors. But one thing is clear: Those laws matter more than a building’s stated rules.
content: Q: During the pandemic, a number of people in my Manhattan co-op have left the city for second homes. Concerned that shareholders were letting visitors stay in the empty apartments, the board enacted a new rule: Shareholders must now request authorization for any overnight guest. I understand the concern, but this rule seems to overstep the board’s authority. Do I need to ask permission if I want an overnight guest to stay with me? As a single woman, I am not comfortable with this invasion of my privacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: How to Make a Chess Set
description: Demand for chess sets is soaring, so why not make your own?
content: Thanks to the success of the Netflix show “The Queen’s Gambit,” chess sets are flying off the shelves. If you can’t find one, or just want another pandemic crafting project, why not make your own at home?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Edward Wong
title: Report Points to Microwave ‘Attack’ as Likely Source of Mystery Illnesses That Hit Diplomats and Spies
description: A government-commissioned report provides the most definitive explanation yet for “Havana syndrome,” which struck scores of American employees, first in Cuba and then in China, Russia and other countries.
content: WASHINGTON — The most probable cause of a series of mysterious afflictions that sickened American spies and diplomats abroad in the past several years was radiofrequency energy, a type of radiation that includes microwaves, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine has concluded in a report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Save New York’s Small Businesses
description: The city’s mom-and-pop establishments need help now.
content: It’s never been easy to run a small business in New York City. The city’s entrepreneurs have long faced dizzying odds: high rents and high taxes, byzantine restrictions from City Hall and fierce competition from corporate big-box stores as well as the bodega next door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Mystery Couple Found in a Roll of Film From Nearly 70 Years Ago
description: Internet sleuths have been captivated by the photos, which were recently developed and document a couple’s trip to the Swiss-Italian border with a dachshund.
content: For nearly 70 years, a partially finished roll of film that documented a couple’s escapades in Switzerland and Italy was hidden away in a brass container, forgotten as it changed hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Bostrom Knausgard
title: A Poet’s View of the Year: Longing for Our Own Lives
description: For the novelist and poet Linda Bostrom Knausgard, 2020 was a period of reflection, and a constant reminder that time is fleeting.
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: After Perilous Atlantic Journey, Migrants Await Their Fate in Canary Island Hotels
description: The Spanish government has put migrants up in hotels as the islands struggle to cope with a rise in arrivals from Africa, but tensions are fraying with locals who fear they’ll scare off tourists.
content: PUERTO RICO, Spain — After braving the Atlantic on a rickety and overcrowded fishing boat for six days, a group of young Senegalese has spent the past three weeks in a three-star hotel in the Canary Islands, overlooking a spectacular beach lapped by pristine waters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon create some shade with an acerbic acrostic.
content: ACROSTIC — This excerpt is a bit of a departure, and not just because its clues come with a colorful visual aid (which I hope solvers see online). It’s about a famously brilliant early film actress and inventor, but half of it is a cutting quote of hers that surprised me, in our comfy old acrostic. I know some of the story — leading movie roles in the 1930s to 1950s, as well as knowledge of radio frequencies that led to important military technology (and even modern Wi-Fi). The book this passage is from, “Hedy’s Folly,” by Richard Rhodes, fleshes all of this out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: One of the First Virus Hot Spots in the U.S. Is Under Siege Again
description: New Rochelle, N.Y., was a model for how to contain and control the coronavirus’s spread. But the city’s success may be fleeting.
content: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — There are lines again at Glen Island Park, the drive-through coronavirus testing center that state officials set up when the coronavirus was discovered in this city in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Joe From Scranton Didn’t Win Back the Working Class
description: An economic analysis of the counties that Joe Biden won and lost shows how the two parties are continuing to realign.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez, Julie Bosman, Amy Harmon, Danielle Ivory and Mitch Smith
title: The Virus Is Devastating the U.S., and Leaving an Uneven Toll
description: The United States saw the most new coronavirus cases of the pandemic on Friday, with deaths and hospitalizations also rising. Underlying conditions largely determine who survives.
content: HOUSTON — The United States is winding up a particularly devastating week, one of the very worst since the coronavirus pandemic began nine months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Fred Sasakamoose, One of the First Indigenous N.H.L. Players, Dies at 86
description: He played only 11 games in hockey’s top league, but he inspired generations of athletes from Canada’s First Nations. He died after suffering complications of the coronavirus.
content: Fred Sasakamoose began skating on blades his grandfather had tied to his moccasins. His hockey stick was a willow branch. A disk of cow manure served as the puck. The rink was a frozen lake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marianne Eloise
title: I’m Autistic. I Didn’t Know Until I Was 27.
description: Autism spectrum disorder is inseparable from who I am. I wish only that it hadn’t taken so long to find out.
content: For my entire life, I have found it very difficult just to exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Edgar Sandoval
title: East Village Fire Damages 128-Year-Old Church
description: The fire tore through a vacant building early Saturday morning and then spread to Middle Collegiate Church on Second Avenue. Four firefighters had minor injuries.
content: A fire in a vacant building in the East Village early Saturday morning spread to a 128-year-old church that houses the New York Liberty Bell, destroying its Gothic-style sanctuary and blowing out the Tiffany stained-glass windows that adorned the stone facade, fire and church officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Two Retiring Senators, Two Divergent Views on How to Save the Senate
description: Senators Lamar Alexander, a Republican, and Tom Udall, a Democrat, agree the institution needs fixing but differ on what the solution is.
content: WASHINGTON — The two senators are friends from opposite parties, both proven legislators with glittery political pedigrees who are leaving Congress on their own terms at the end of this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Candice Bergen, Woman Who’s Had It All
description: The wryest of Hollywood royals recalls life with Daddy’s dummy, marriage to Louis Malle and a comedic career for the ages.
content: There may be some things more fun than hanging out with Candice Bergen and talking about Michael Caine, Sean Connery, Steve McQueen, Jack Nicholson, Princess Diana, Princess Grace, John Belushi, Donald Trump, Charles Manson, getting fat, getting old, getting wrinkled and not giving a damn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Michael D. Shear
title: ‘They’re Playing With Our Lives’: What Happens Next for DACA’s ‘Dreamers’
description: A judge ordered the Trump administration to reinstate protections for young immigrants brought to the country as children. But their status remains precarious.
content: LOS ANGELES — Despite being a college graduate, Maria Fernanda Madrigal Delgado had no choice in 2011 but to clean buildings and flip burgers in fast-food joints for cash because she was not eligible to work in the United States. She had grown up undocumented in Southern California after being brought to the country as a child from Costa Rica.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Cynthia Lummis, a Bull-Coaxing Conservative, Heads to the Senate
description: A right-wing rancher with a libertarian streak, Ms. Lummis, who served four terms in the House, is the first woman to represent Wyoming in the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — The bull Romeo stood in the middle of 2,000-acre pasture near Cheyenne, Wyo., suffering from foot rot. Even though Cynthia Lummis lacked a horse, it was her job, as the ranch owner, to get this moody and aggressive animal into a trailer and to the vet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Responding to Terrorism in France
description: President Emmanuel Macron and others there have been angered by outside criticism.
content: In the wake of two horrific incidents of Islamist terrorism in France, President Emmanuel Macron and many of his countrymen have reacted angrily to criticism from abroad suggesting that French policies, and especially the French version of state-enforced secularism, somehow contributed to the lethal radicalization of a sliver of the country’s large Muslim population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivienne Westwood
title: The World According to Vivienne Westwood
description: For the fashion designer and punk icon, 2020 has been a time for reflection on art, politics and new ways to save the planet.
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson and Michael D. Shear
title: Judge Orders Government to Fully Reinstate DACA Program
description: Up to 300,000 additional undocumented immigrants could be allowed to apply for protection from deportation under a new court ruling. President Trump had sought to cancel the program.
content: A federal judge on Friday ordered the Trump administration to fully restore an Obama-era program designed to shield young, undocumented immigrants from deportation, dealing what could be a final blow to President Trump’s long-fought effort to end the protections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Venezuela to Vote in an Election the Opposition Calls a Charade
description: A victory by the party of President Nicolás Maduro is likely to further weaken Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader who launched a bold but ultimately failed bid backed by the U.S. to take power.
content: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the years since the Venezuelan crisis began, Yajaira Paz, 35, has lost nearly everything to its fallout: her mother, dead from a heart problem she could not afford to treat; her brothers, to migration; her faith in democracy, to the nation’s crippled institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump’s Final Days of Rage and Denial
description: The last act of the Trump presidency has taken on the stormy elements of a drama more common to history or literature than a modern White House.
content: WASHINGTON — Over the past week, President Trump posted or reposted about 145 messages on Twitter lashing out at the results of an election he lost. He mentioned the coronavirus pandemic now reaching its darkest hours four times — and even then just to assert that he was right about the outbreak and the experts were wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: As Deadline Lapses, Trump Administration Continues TikTok Talks
description: The White House did not extend a Dec. 4 deadline for the Chinese internet company ByteDance to sell TikTok.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will allow a Friday deadline for TikTok’s Chinese parent company to sell the viral video app to lapse, said a person with knowledge of the decision. But the government will continue to work on a deal that would put a larger slice of TikTok’s ownership in American hands, the person said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pavin Chachavalpongpun
title: A King Above and Beyond Politics
description: Why are the people of Thailand rising up against royal power now?
content: Several thousand people dressed in yellow or pink, colors associated with the royal family of Thailand, gathered along the road to the Grand Palace in Bangkok on Saturday to celebrate the birthday of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: William Aronwald, Target of a Botched Mob Hit, Dies at 79
description: He was a prominent prosecutor in the 1970s. A blunder by hit men left his father dead.
content: William I. Aronwald died on Oct. 29. If not for the ineptitude of a couple of mob hit men, he might never have made it out of the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Death Came for the Dakotas
description: In terms of the coronavirus, they’re a theater of American disgrace.
content: Under normal circumstances, I would have flown to one or both of the Dakotas to write this column, but the whole point is that these aren’t normal circumstances. And I don’t have a death wish.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Outcry Over Sex Testing Grows Louder
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 5, 2020.
content: “They treat us as if we are cheats. We deserve to be respected as athletes, as champions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: In Somalia, U.S. Troop Withdrawal Is Seen as Badly Timed
description: Somali presidential elections are scheduled in just a few months, war is erupting in neighboring Ethiopia, and Shebab militants are still strong. The timing, Somalis say, could not be worse.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somalis fear a U.S. decision to withdraw troops from their country will be seen as a victory for the Qaeda-linked militants who have wreaked havoc there for years, and sow the potential for further chaos at an especially delicate moment for Somalia and the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: As Refugees, Their Options Were Limited. Others Saw a Profit.
description: Even after decades in Thailand, Kayan women who fled Myanmar make their living from their traditional neck rings. But that’s changing.
content: HUAY PU KENG, Thailand — In front of nearly every bamboo home in the village of Huay Pu Keng are stalls selling trinkets related to the neck rings that women from the Kayan ethnic group traditionally wear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By June Canedo and Erick Galindo
title: The ‘Mexican Beverly Hills’
description: How a former white enclave became an aspirational suburb for Latinos in Los Angeles.
content: I was having dinner at some fancy beach-side eatery in early March when someone said they had just moved to Downey, a Southeast Los Angeles suburb 12 miles south of downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
title: With 3 Billion Packages to Go, Online Shopping Faces Tough Holiday Test
description: The season is adding pressure on retailers, strained by a pandemic surge in e-commerce and limited by shippers, to deliver gifts on time.
content: E-commerce became a lifeline for consumers and companies during the pandemic. But this holiday season, online shopping will strain the industry as never before: An estimated three billion packages will course through the nation’s shipping infrastructure — about 800 million more than delivered last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: If It’s Fiction, Can It Be an Invasion of Privacy?
description: Emmanuel Carrère’s latest novel, “Yoga,” has stoked debate in France after the author’s ex-wife, Hélène Devynck, accused him of writing about her without her consent.
content: When nonfiction writers face backlash for their depictions of loved ones, the disputes tend to center on how far their indiscretions have stretched. But what happens when someone no longer wants to appear in an ex-partner’s work, period?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Jim Rutenberg
title: Republicans Pushed to Restrict Voting. Millions of Americans Pushed Back.
description: Almost 160 million people voted this year, as new options made necessary by the pandemic removed many of the traditional barriers to casting ballots. Will it change the way America conducts elections?
content: Nearly 160 million Americans voted in the 2020 elections, by far the most in history and a level of turnout not seen in over a century, representing an extraordinary milestone of civic engagement in a year marked by a devastating pandemic, record unemployment and political unrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn, Christopher Flavelle and Daniel Berehulak
title: A Race Against Time to Rescue a Reef From Climate Change
description: In an unusual experiment, a coral reef in Mexico is now insured against hurricanes. A team of locals known as “the Brigade” rushed to repair the devastated corals, piece by piece.
content: When Hurricane Delta hit Puerto Morelos, Mexico, in October, a team known as the Brigade waited anxiously for the sea to quiet. The group, an assortment of tour guides, diving instructors, park rangers, fishermen and researchers, needed to get in the water as soon as possible. The coral reef that protects their town — an undersea forest of living limestone branches that blunted the storm’s destructive power — had taken a beating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Wegman
title: 2020 Through the Eyes of Dogs
description: We asked the photographer William Wegman what he (and his famous canine muses) thought of this year.
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Is ‘Natural Immunity’ From Covid Better Than a Vaccine?
description: And if you’ve already had Covid-19, do you still need a vaccine? Experts tackle questions about vaccine immunity.
content: On the heels of last month’s news of stunning results from Pfizer’s and Moderna’s experimental Covid-19 vaccines, Senator Rand Paul tweeted a provocative comparison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: The Rise and Fall of Carl Lentz, the Celebrity Pastor of Hillsong Church
description: A charismatic pastor helped build a megachurch favored by star athletes and entertainers — until some temptations became too much to resist.
content: In the summer of 2017, the singer Justin Bieber abruptly canceled the remainder of a concert tour that had taken him across six continents in 16 months. Mr. Bieber cited fatigue; his fans fretted. But on the tabloid website TMZ, a more hopeful narrative quickly emerged. The 23-year-old singer left the tour because he “rededicated his life to Christ” thanks to a pastor named Carl Lentz, leader of the New York City branch of the global megachurch Hillsong. The pastor and the pop star were inseparable, the gossip site reported. Two days later, the site reported that Mr. Bieber saw Mr. Lentz “as a 2nd father.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Liberty Win the W.N.B.A. Draft Lottery Again
description: The team, which took Sabrina Ionescu in the most recent draft, got the top pick for a second consecutive year. The choice will be more complicated this time.
content: The Liberty will pick No. 1 for a second consecutive year in the W.N.B.A. draft, the league announced on Friday night. This time, the leading candidate to be the first pick is not nearly as clear as the last time, when the Liberty chose Oregon’s Sabrina Ionescu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: The Swiss Cheese Model of Pandemic Defense
description: It’s not edible, but it can save lives. The virologist Ian Mackay explains how.
content: Lately, in the ongoing conversation about how to defeat the coronavirus, experts have made reference to the “Swiss cheese model” of pandemic defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Warren Berlinger, Film and Television Character Actor, Dies at 83
description: Mr. Berlinger, who had dozens of roles in a career that spanned more than six decades, appeared in “Happy Days” and “The Cannonball Run.”
content: Warren Berlinger, whose career as a character actor spanned more than six decades and featured myriad roles in film and television dramas and comedies, died on Wednesday at the Henry Mayo Newhall Hospital in Santa Clarita, Calif. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Police Drones Are Starting to Think for Themselves
description: In one Southern California city, flying drones with artificial intelligence are aiding investigations while presenting new civil rights questions.
content: CHULA VISTA, Calif. — When the Chula Vista police receive a 911 call, they can dispatch a flying drone with the press of a button.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon
title: At Rally for Georgia Senators, Trump Focuses on His Own Grievances
description: The president falsely claimed the election was rigged and that he had won. Earlier, he urged Georgia’s governor to call a special legislative session to overturn Joe Biden’s win in the state.
content: VALDOSTA, Ga. — One month before a pair of Georgia runoffs that will determine the Senate majority, President Trump used a rally for the Republican senators on Saturday to complain about his own loss last month, insisting he would still prevail and, with notably less ardor, encouraging voters here to re-elect the two lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: As Premier League Gates Reopen, a Soothing Soundtrack Returns
description: The return of a few thousand fans to Premier League stadiums was a reminder that it’s not only their roars that we’ve missed.
content: LONDON — The stillness spoke volumes. There were 12 minutes left to play, but the game was over. Manchester United’s players were swarming around Marcus Rashford, scorer of his team’s third goal, the one that had settled matters. West Ham’s were staring blankly at the turf, unsure of quite how things had slipped away from them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Vaccines End the Pandemic’s Political Harmony
description: Erin O’Toole, the Conservative leader, is using the government’s vaccine plans to begin his first big political attack on Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.
content: This week people in Britain learned that a coronavirus vaccine will soon be on its way — at least for the first batch of people. In Canada, however, vaccines were the focus of political squabbling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greek Orthodox Church Faces Criticism as Virus Hits Its Ranks
description: Church leaders have backed government restrictions, but defiance by hard-liners and a commitment to the sacrament of communion, taken with a shared spoon, may undercut good intentions.
content: ATHENS — The coronavirus has dealt a double blow to the powerful Greek Orthodox Church, with the disease spreading through its ranks while the clergy fends off criticism that it has been stoking the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: And Play Like a Girl She Did
description: Vanderbilt’s Sarah Fuller is the first woman to play Power 5 football. She’s been a long time coming.
content: NASHVILLE — When Sarah Fuller stepped onto the field at the University of Missouri on Nov. 28, she wasn’t wearing the jersey she normally wears as a goalkeeper for Vanderbilt University’s women’s soccer team. On that Saturday after Thanksgiving, she was wearing full pads and a Commodores football jersey. Her helmet was emblazoned with the words “Play Like a Girl.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough and Jan Hoffman
title: The Elderly vs. Essential Workers: Who Should Get the Coronavirus Vaccine First?
description: The C.D.C. will soon decide which group to recommend next, and the debate over the trade-offs is growing heated. Ultimately, states will determine whom to include.
content: With the coronavirus pandemic surging and initial vaccine supplies limited, the United States faces a hard choice: Should the country’s immunization program focus in the early months on the elderly and people with serious medical conditions, who are dying of the virus at the highest rates, or on essential workers, an expansive category encompassing Americans who have borne the greatest risk of infection?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima Faizi and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Suhaila Siddiq, Afghanistan’s First Female General, Is Dead
description: Also a renowned surgeon, she rose through the ranks of the Afghan Army and practiced medicine during the Soviet invasion and the Afghan civil war and under the Taliban’s rule.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Suhaila Siddiq, Afghanistan’s first female lieutenant general, who was also a renowned surgeon and unknowingly became a feminist role model in a largely patriarchal society, died here on Friday, at the same hospital where she had treated the wounded and weary of her country’s unending war for decades. She was thought to be 81 or 82, though her exact birth date is unknown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Get Out of Here!
description: Wait, no, not yet — come do this Tony Orbach Sunday special.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I defy anyone to not try to come up with examples of this theme for the rest of the day, once they’ve gotten to the bottom of this nifty grid by Tony Orbach, who has been a master of Sunday Times crosswords since 2006. It’s as natural as going out to breathe fresh air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Manners
title: Festive Holiday Gifts for Newlyweds
description: Event planners and culinary professionals share some suggestions to help couples celebrate the season in style.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has given new meaning to being home for the holidays this year. Most newlyweds will have to celebrate their first Christmas, Kwanzaa, Hanukkah or New Year’s Eve in more intimate settings because of social-distancing requirements, but they can still do it in style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Michael D. Shear and Shane Goldmacher
title: A Gathering Political Storm Hits Georgia, With Trump on the Way
description: With two crucial Senate seats up for grabs, Mike Pence and Barack Obama joined the fray in support of their party’s candidates, and President Trump is headed there on Saturday.
content: ATLANTA — Some of the biggest names in national politics jumped into the fiercely contested runoffs for two Georgia Senate seats on Friday, even as a second recount showed that Joseph R. Biden Jr. had maintained his lead in the state and Republicans braced for a visit by President Trump, who has railed against his loss there with baseless claims of fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan C. Lipson and Gerald Posner
title: The Sacklers’ Last Poison Pill
description: A trapdoor in the Justice Department deal with the family’s company might enable them to escape a full accounting of their part in the opioid epidemic.
content: The opioid crisis remains one of America’s deadliest public health disasters. Victims demand answers about how it happened and who was responsible.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Make This French Onion Galette
description: Make Sue Li’s recipe, or any of the most popular recipes of the week.
content: This weekend make Sue Li’s caramelized onion galette (above), inspired by the flavors of French onion soup, Dorie Greenspan’s lemon meringue cookies or Ali Slagle’s three-cup vegetables. Find more of NYT Cooking’s most popular recipes of the week in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Japan’s Journey to an Asteroid Ends With a Hunt in Australia’s Outback
description: The Hayabusa2 mission cements Japan’s role in exploring the solar system, but finding its asteroid cargo presented one last challenge.
content: This weekend, Japan’s space agency concluded a journey of discovery that aims to shed light on the earliest eons of the solar system and possibly provide clues about the origins of life on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Diabolical
description: Get sucked into this Brendan Emmett Quigley construction, if you dare!
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We are lucky to get a lot of puzzles out of Brendan Emmett Quigley, but he hasn’t had a Saturday grid for The New York Times since 2012 — I imagine that today’s construction was deemed a soupçon too difficult for a Friday. For some reason I picture the entire thing swirling into creation around one particular factoid, but you may have a very different take depending on where your interests lie, which is how a toothsome themeless should be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: J.K. Rowling’s New Non-Potter Children’s Book
description: If “The Ickabog” — about a land of plenty that due to a monstrous lie becomes a land of fear — sounds familiar, it’s pure coincidence. Really.
content: THE ICKABOGBy J.K. RowlingWith illustrations by the winners of The Ickabog Illustration Competition
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Remy Tumin
title: Europe’s Deadly Second Wave
description: Summer vacations led to fall lockdowns. How did the world’s richest club of nations let it happen again?
content: By early June, Europe was emerging from the depths of its fight against the coronavirus, just as the U.S. and others were fighting record caseloads. Europeans, desperate for a break, headed off for their sacred summer vacations — and paid dearly for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Decency Agenda
description: Joe Biden promised to be a president for all Americans. Here’s a way to start.
content: Joe Biden won the presidency because, at a moment when so many Americans were exhausted by the chaos and nastiness of the Trump era, he promised stability, decency and healing. At the heart of his candidacy was the vow to be “a president for all Americans” as he labored “to restore the soul of the nation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Emily Bazelon
title: Flaws in Census Count Imperil Trump Plan to Exclude Undocumented Immigrants
description: More problems arise as the Census Bureau rushes to compile information needed for apportionment before President Trump leaves office.
content: WASHINGTON — Census Bureau experts have uncovered serious flaws in a section of the 2020 head count that potentially affect the enumeration of millions, according to people familiar with the census operations, delaying still further the completion of state-by-state population totals that the White House has demanded before President Trump leaves office next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Do So Many Americans Think the Election Was Stolen?
description: Looking for the reasons behind a seemingly unreasonable belief.
content: There have been few surprises this past month in how Donald Trump has dealt with the reality of his electoral defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum and Carl Zimmer
title: How Pfizer’s Vaccine Works
description: Two shots can prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.
content: Two shots can prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum and Carl Zimmer
title: How Moderna’s Vaccine Works
description: Two shots can prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.
content: Two shots can prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.

title: Corrections: Dec. 5, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 5, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about contenders for energy and climate positions in the Biden administration misstated the name of the organization that Heather McTeer Toney leads. It is Moms Clean Air Force, not Mom’s Clean Air Task Force.
source.name: The New York Times
